question: What is the etiologic agent of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy ?:
prompt:
What is the etiologic agent of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy ?:A)Polyomavirus JC.
B)West Nile virus.
C)Herpes human virus type 6.
D)Poliovirus
output0: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is caused by the Polyomavirus JC. This virus is a common etiologic agent of this condition, and is thought to be responsible for the majority of cases.
output1: West Nile virus is the etiologic agent of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML). PML is a rare but serious neurological disorder that can cause inflammation and damage to the brain.
output2: The etiologic agent of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is the herpes simplex virus type 6 (HHV-6). This virus is known to cause PML, a rare but potentially life-threatening condition that affects the brain.
output3: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is caused by the poliovirus. This virus is a member of the Picornaviridae family and is responsible for the development of the disease.

question: Tears contain an ingredient that following, biodegradable wins peptidoglycan (peptidoglycan)?
prompt:
Tears contain an ingredient that following, biodegradable wins peptidoglycan (peptidoglycan)?A)Lactoferrin protein (Lactoferrin)
B)Lytic 酶 (Lysozyme)
C)Lactoperoxidase (Lactoperoxidase)
D)Amylase (Amylase)
output0: Lactoferrin is a protein found in tears that has antimicrobial properties, which can help to break down the peptidoglycan in the cell walls of bacteria. This makes it an important component of the immune system in the eyes.
output1: Lysozyme is an enzyme that is found in tears and is responsible for breaking down the peptidoglycan layer of bacterial cell walls. This makes it an important component of the body's defense against bacterial infections.
output2: Lactoperoxidase is a protein found in tears that has antimicrobial properties, which helps to protect the eyes from infection. It is also involved in the breakdown of the peptidoglycan, which is a component of the cell walls of bacteria.
output3: Amylase is an enzyme that breaks down carbohydrates and is present in tears. It is not present in peptidoglycan, which is a component of the cell wall of bacteria.

question: While measuring blood pressure of a cardiac tamponade patient, what advice will you give him:
prompt:
While measuring blood pressure of a cardiac tamponade patient, what advice will you give him:A)Hold breath
B)Breathe normally
C)I.ong and deep breathing
D)Sho and shallow breaths
output0: When measuring blood pressure of a cardiac tamponade patient, it is important to advise them to hold their breath. This is because cardiac tamponade can cause a drop in blood pressure, and taking a deep breath can exacerbate this effect. By holding their breath, the patient can avoid this drop in blood pressure and help ensure that the blood pressure reading is accurate.
output1: When measuring blood pressure of a cardiac tamponade patient, it is important to have the patient breathe normally. This will help to ensure that the blood pressure reading is accurate and not affected by any changes in respiration.
output2: When measuring blood pressure of a cardiac tamponade patient, it is important to instruct them to take long and deep breaths to help them relax and achieve a more accurate reading.
output3: When measuring blood pressure in a patient with cardiac tamponade, it is important to instruct the patient to take shallow and slow breaths, as deep breathing can increase the pressure in the chest and worsen the condition.

question: Cerebral palsy (cerebral palsy) in patients with bone and joint complications in patients with cerebral palsy which groups most prone to dislocation of the hip (hip joint displacement)?
correct_answer: Quadriplegic type (quadriplegic) in patients with cerebral palsy
options: A)Half of the paralytic (hemiplegic) cerebral palsy
B)Quadriplegic type (quadriplegic) in patients with cerebral palsy
D)Bilateral paralysis type (diplegic) in patients with cerebral palsy
prompt:
Cerebral palsy (cerebral palsy) in patients with bone and joint complications in patients with cerebral palsy which groups most prone to dislocation of the hip (hip joint displacement)?A)Half of the paralytic (hemiplegic) cerebral palsy
B)Quadriplegic type (quadriplegic) in patients with cerebral palsy
C)Dyskinesia type (dyskinetic) cerebral palsy
D)Bilateral paralysis type (diplegic) in patients with cerebral palsy
output0: Half of the paralytic (hemiplegic) cerebral palsy is the most prone to dislocation of the hip (hip joint displacement) due to the weakness and paralysis of one side of the body. This can lead to an imbalance in the muscles and joints, causing the hip joint to become displaced.
output1: Quadriplegic cerebral palsy is the most common type of cerebral palsy associated with hip joint displacement. This is because the paralysis affects all four limbs, which can cause instability in the hip joint and increase the risk of dislocation.
output2: Dyskinesia type cerebral palsy is characterized by involuntary movements and muscle spasms, which can lead to an increased risk of joint dislocation, including the hip joint. This group is therefore the most prone to dislocation of the hip.
output3: Bilateral paralysis type (diplegic) cerebral palsy is the most prone to dislocation of the hip (hip joint displacement) due to the lack of muscle strength and control on both sides of the body. This type of cerebral palsy can lead to a condition known as "hip joint displacement" which can cause pain, stiffness, and difficulty walking.

question: Most common cause of maternal moality in spinal anesthesia is ?
prompt:
Most common cause of maternal moality in spinal anesthesia is ?A)Allergy to local anesthesia
B)Nerve injury
C)High block
D)Hypotension
output0: The most common cause of maternal mortality in spinal anesthesia is an allergic reaction to the local anesthetic. This is because the local anesthetic is injected directly into the spinal fluid, and if the mother has an allergy, it can cause a severe and potentially life-threatening reaction.
output1: The most common cause of maternal mortality in spinal anesthesia is nerve injury, which can lead to severe neurological deficits and death. This is because the spinal cord is a delicate structure that can be easily damaged by the needle used for spinal anesthesia.
output2: The most common cause of maternal mortality in spinal anesthesia is a high block, which can lead to respiratory depression and cardiac arrest.
output3: Hypotension is the most common cause of maternal mortality in spinal anesthesia. This is because the local anesthetic can cause a drop in blood pressure, which can lead to inadequate perfusion of vital organs.

question: What is the only natural reservoir of Mycobacterium tuberculosis?
prompt:
What is the only natural reservoir of Mycobacterium tuberculosis?A)Ape.
B)Human.
C)Rats
D)Cattle.
output0: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacteria that causes TB, is only found in apes, specifically chimpanzees and gorillas. These animals are the natural reservoir for the bacteria, meaning they can carry and transmit the bacteria without becoming sick themselves.
output1: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacteria that causes tuberculosis, is a human-specific pathogen. It does not naturally infect animals, and rats and other animals are not considered natural reservoirs of the bacteria.
output2: Rats are the only natural reservoir of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which is the bacterium that causes tuberculosis.
output3: Cattle are the only natural reservoir of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. This means that they can carry the bacteria without showing any symptoms, and can potentially infect other animals and humans.

question:
59 A 42-year-old woman nearly three years right ear hearing loss gradually, often dizziness, vertigo occasionally there will be a phenomenon of the right side of the peripheral facial palsy (peripheral type facial palsy) appeared a week ago. Brainstem auditory evoked potential (brainstem auditory evoked potential) examination revealed cochlear lesions (retrocochlear pathology). In terms of family history, patients suffering from both sides of the brother
 Acoustic neuroma. Which of the following is most likely to patients suffering from hereditary diseases?
options: B)The first type of neurofibromatosis (neurofibromatosis type I)
prompt:
59 A 42-year-old woman nearly three years right ear hearing loss gradually, often dizziness, vertigo occasionally there will be a phenomenon of the right side of the peripheral facial palsy (peripheral type facial palsy) appeared a week ago. Brainstem auditory evoked potential (brainstem auditory evoked potential) examination revealed cochlear lesions (retrocochlear pathology). In terms of family history, patients suffering from both sides of the brother
 Acoustic neuroma. Which of the following is most likely to patients suffering from hereditary diseases?
A)Tuberous sclerosis (tuberous sclerosis)
B)The first type of neurofibromatosis (neurofibromatosis type I)
C)Mr. Tang disease (Down syndrome)
D)Type II neurofibromatosis (neurofibromatosis type II)
output0: The patient's family history of acoustic neuroma on both sides of the brother suggests that the patient may have a hereditary condition. Tuberous sclerosis is a rare inherited disorder that is characterized by the growth of non-cancerous tumors in various organs, including the brain, and is associated with an increased risk of developing acoustic neuroma. The other options, neurofibromatosis type I, Mr. Tang disease, and neurofibromatosis type II, are not typically associated with acoustic neuroma.
output1: The patient's family history of acoustic neuroma on both sides of the brother, and the patient's own symptoms of hearing loss, dizziness, and peripheral facial palsy suggest a possible hereditary condition. Neurofibromatosis type I is the most likely diagnosis, as it is the most common inherited condition that affects the auditory nerve and can cause hearing loss, balance problems, and facial palsy.
output2: Patients with hereditary diseases are more likely to suffer from hereditary diseases, such as Down syndrome (Mr. Tang disease). Acoustic neuroma is a type of benign tumor that can occur in individuals with Down syndrome. Therefore, the correct answer is C)Mr. Tang disease (Down syndrome).
output3: Type II neurofibromatosis (NF2) is a hereditary disease that affects the development of the auditory nerve and other sensory nerves. It is characterized by the growth of tumors on the nerve sheaths, which can cause hearing loss, facial palsy, and other symptoms. Since the patient's brother has acoustic neuroma, it is likely that the patient also has a genetic predisposition to NF2.

question: Rolling of leucocytes on endothelial cells is mediated by
prompt:
Rolling of leucocytes on endothelial cells is mediated byA)ICAM-1
B)(3, integrin
C)IL-8
D)P- selectin
output0: The interaction between leucocytes and endothelial cells is mediated by several molecules, including ICAM-1 (Intracellular Adhesion Molecule-1). ICAM-1 is a glycoprotein that is expressed on endothelial cells and binds to integrins on the surface of leucocytes, allowing them to adhere to the endothelium and roll along it.
output1: Rolling of leucocytes on endothelial cells is mediated by (3, integrin, which is a type of adhesion molecule. This molecule allows the leucocytes to bind to the endothelial cells and to roll along the endothelial surface.
output2: Rolling of leucocytes on endothelial cells is mediated by the chemokine IL-8. IL-8 binds to its receptor on the surface of endothelial cells, which causes the cells to become more permeable and allows leucocytes to roll along the endothelial surface.
output3: Rolling of leucocytes on endothelial cells is mediated by P-selectin, a protein that is expressed on the surface of endothelial cells and interacts with the integrin receptors on the surface of leucocytes.

question: A pregnant female had Meconium stained liquor and underwent emergency LSCS. A few days later her condition deteriorated. USG showed edematous bowels. What's the cause?
prompt:
A pregnant female had Meconium stained liquor and underwent emergency LSCS. A few days later her condition deteriorated. USG showed edematous bowels. What's the cause?A)Meconium peritonitis
B)Paralytic ileus
C)Adhesive intestinal obstruction
D)Intra-abdominal abscess
output0: Meconium peritonitis is a possible complication of a Meconium stained liquor during labor. It occurs when the Meconium enters the peritoneal cavity and causes inflammation. The symptoms of Meconium peritonitis can include abdominal pain, fever, and distension of the bowels. In this case, the USG showed edematous bowels, which is a common finding in Meconium peritonitis.
output1: Paralytic ileus is a common complication after an emergency cesarean section, especially when there is meconium stained liquor. It occurs when the parasympathetic nervous system is overactive, causing the intestines to become paralyzed and unable to move. This can lead to edematous bowels and other complications.
output2: The cause of the deterioration in the pregnant female's condition a few days after emergency LSCS with meconium stained liquor is likely to be adhesive intestinal obstruction. This is because meconium can cause adhesions to form between the intestines and other organs, leading to bowel obstruction.
output3: The patient's condition deteriorating a few days after an emergency LSCS, with edematous bowels on USG, is consistent with an intra-abdominal abscess. Meconium peritonitis, paralytic ileus, and adhesive intestinal obstruction are less likely causes of this presentation.

question: Most common influenza virus causing disease?
prompt:
Most common influenza virus causing disease?A)Type A
B)Type B
C)Type C
D)Type D
output0: Type A is the most common influenza virus causing disease. This type of virus is responsible for most seasonal outbreaks of the flu and is more likely to cause severe illness and pandemics.
output1: Type B is the most common influenza virus causing disease. This virus is responsible for most cases of seasonal flu and is highly contagious.
output2: The most common influenza virus causing disease is Type C. This is because Type C viruses are the most prevalent and account for the majority of influenza cases in children.
output3: The most common influenza virus causing disease is Type D. Type D is the most prevalent type of influenza virus and is responsible for the majority of influenza outbreaks.
